Headline: Application Intent Summary

current_job_data.title: Distributed Systems Engineer
current_job_data.description:
About the job

Distributed Systems Engineer - Global Quant Trading Firm | Up to £400k TC

A globally recognised and fast-growing quantitative trading firm are searching for a Distributed Systems Engineer to help design and optimise their distributed computing environment. 




You’ll be working in a highly complex and technical environment, contributing to the performance and scalability of large-scale systems that underpin the firm's quantitative research and trading platforms. The team has a deep engineering culture, flat structure, and a strong focus on technical excellence.

 

Below I have included a breakdown of the role, company, and requirements. Please review and if the opportunity seems like a good fit share your CV!

 

Role:

Architect and optimise large-scale compute-intensive workloads spanning significant numbers of nodes and concurrent tasks
Design, build, and manage systems with tools like Ray and YellowDog
Optimise application performance on distributed platforms
Provide architectural guidance on distributed computing design and development
Drive efficiency and scalability across the platform, with a focus on ML pipeline execution

 

Company:

Technology-led culture – Drives both trading and internal investment decisions
c.1,000 employees – Large enough for scale, small enough for individual impact
New state-of-the-art London HQ – Core hub for engineering and trading, Free On-Site Gym
Flat structure – Direct access to senior engineers and C-level leaders
Strong Glassdoor rating
Great work life balance (frequently quoted on Glassdoor) - Free Breakfast and Lunch, 2 days per week WFH
Competitive Compensation - Year 1 guaranteed bonus, 13% pension, Potential for Sign-On Bonuses

 

Requirements:

Understanding of Loosely/Tightly coupled workloads
HPC platform experience
Job/Resource scheduling experience i.e. Yellowdog
Cloud platform proficiency (any provider)
Experience with large scale systems (1k+ Nodes, 10k+ tasks)
Experience monitoring/troubleshooting a distributed environment
Advance Ray experience for ML pipelines, tuning, distributed execution
Python and Conda proficiency
Docker + Kubernetes experience
Knowledge of networking (TCP/IP, UDP/IP, LAN/WAN)
Identify and access management knowledge
current_job_data.description_html:
About the job

Distributed Systems Engineer - Global Quant Trading Firm | Up to £400k TC

A globally recognised and fast-growing quantitative trading firm are searching for a Distributed Systems Engineer to help design and optimise their distributed computing environment.


You’ll be working in a highly complex and technical environment, contributing to the performance and scalability of large-scale systems that underpin the firm's quantitative research and trading platforms. The team has a deep engineering culture, flat structure, and a strong focus on technical excellence.

Below I have included a breakdown of the role, company, and requirements. Please review and if the opportunity seems like a good fit share your CV!

Role:
  • Architect and optimise large-scale compute-intensive workloads spanning significant numbers of nodes and concurrent tasks
  • Design, build, and manage systems with tools like Ray and YellowDog
  • Optimise application performance on distributed platforms
  • Provide architectural guidance on distributed computing design and development
  • Drive efficiency and scalability across the platform, with a focus on ML pipeline execution

Company:
  • Technology-led culture – Drives both trading and internal investment decisions
  • c.1,000 employees – Large enough for scale, small enough for individual impact
  • New state-of-the-art London HQ – Core hub for engineering and trading, Free On-Site Gym
  • Flat structure – Direct access to senior engineers and C-level leaders
  • Strong Glassdoor rating
  • Great work life balance (frequently quoted on Glassdoor) - Free Breakfast and Lunch, 2 days per week WFH
  • Competitive Compensation - Year 1 guaranteed bonus, 13% pension, Potential for Sign-On Bonuses

Requirements:
  • Understanding of Loosely/Tightly coupled workloads
  • HPC platform experience
  • Job/Resource scheduling experience i.e. Yellowdog
  • Cloud platform proficiency (any provider)
  • Experience with large scale systems (1k+ Nodes, 10k+ tasks)
  • Experience monitoring/troubleshooting a distributed environment
  • Advance Ray experience for ML pipelines, tuning, distributed execution
  • Python and Conda proficiency
  • Docker + Kubernetes experience
  • Knowledge of networking (TCP/IP, UDP/IP, LAN/WAN)
  • Identify and access management knowledge

Cover letter:
Dear Hiring Manager,

I am writing to express my interest in the Data Engineer position at Thomas. I was excited to learn about this opportunity and believe my skills and experience align well with the requirements of the role.

As a Data Scientist and ML Engineer with experience in full-stack development, I bring a diverse skillset that encompasses Python programming, machine learning model development, and building end-to-end AI applications. My background in physics has provided me with strong analytical and problem-solving skills that I apply to technical challenges.

Some of my key projects include developing a wildfire detection system with machine learning, creating a personal AI image generation mobile application, and building an autonomous drone navigation system. These experiences have equipped me with the technical knowledge and practical skills necessary for this role.

I am particularly interested in joining Thomas because of its reputation for innovation. I am confident that my background and enthusiasm make me a strong candidate for this position.

I welcome the opportunity to discuss how my qualifications match your needs. Thank you for considering my application.

Sincerely,
Matthaios Markatis

Although I have yet to directly engage within the construction sector, I am eager and committed to adapting my robust project management skills and deep technical knowledge to meet the rigorous demands and excellence that this role requires at Optimise by Recruitment.

My academic background in physics from the University of Sheffield, combined with hands-on experience in data science and AI engineering, equips me with the technical depth and analytical skills required for this role.

The prospect of engaging with tightly integrated AWS services like ECS, ECR, and Lambda aligns perfectly with my experience and enthusiasm for cloud-based applications. I am particularly excited about the opportunity to contribute to and shape the company's technological strategy by bringing forth my experience in modern PHP and JavaScript frameworks like Laravel and React, and my proficiency in CI/CD and DevOps practices, notably with GitHub Actions.

I am impressed by the company’s commitment to encouraging autonomy and innovative problem-solving. My previous projects, such as collaborating on a real-time wildfire detection system and an AI-based image generation app, demonstrate my ability to tackle complex challenges and develop robust, scalable solutions that align with Vero HR’s innovative ethos.

Moreover, the chance to work remotely yet still interact with a vibrant team during in-person meetings excites me as it offers the flexibility and team interaction I value. The comprehensive benefits package further enhances my attraction to this role, promising both professional growth and personal well-being.

Overall, I am eager to bring my full-stack development skills and a proactive, detail-oriented approach to the dynamic environment at Vero HR, contributing to groundbreaking solutions within the fintech space.

I am an accomplished Full-Stack Developer with a strong background in both PHP and JavaScript, making me a suitable candidate for the Full-Stack PHP Developer position at Vero HR. Holding a BSc in Physics from the University of Sheffield, I have honed my computational skills and have gained extensive experience in both front-end and back-end development.

My technical toolkit extends to AWS services, including ECS and Lambda, and familiarity with Docker, vital for handling scalable, cloud-native applications. I've tackled complex architectural problems in prior projects, employing defensive programming techniques to bolster security and efficacy.

I thrive on solving challenging problems independently, and my collaborative experience in high-pressure environments has finely tuned my communication skills, both with technical peers and non-technical stakeholders. I am eager to leverage my skills to contribute to Vero HR's ongoing technological strategy as part of a forward-thinking fintech team.

My technical proficiency includes JavaScript/TypeScript, with expertise in frameworks such as React and Node.js, crucial for frontend and backend development respectively. Do you have a Bachelor\u2019s or Master\: Yes, I hold a BSc in Physics from the University of Sheffield, which is directly relevant to the fields of data science and artificial intelligence due to its emphasis on computational methods, advanced programming, and statistical analysis. Through my degree, I undertook modules in advanced Python programming, physical computing, and AI-driven research, and I further solidified my expertise by completing both the IBM Data Science and IBM AI Engineering Professional Certificates. These provided deep, hands-on experience in machine learning, model deployment, and end-to-end AI system design. My background has prepared me extensively to contribute to high-impact AI engineering teams like Vable’s, and I am eager to leverage my academic and technical foundation to help deliver innovative AI solutions for your clients.
Tell us how you have a minimum of 3 year:
While my professional full-time experience does not yet total three years, I have a robust and diverse foundation in polyglot software engineering, end-to-end development, and AI application deployment. My BSc in Physics from the University of Sheffield included advanced programming modules in Python and foundational studies in computer science principles, complemented by self-directed projects and industry-recognized IBM certifications in Data Science and AI Engineering. 

Throughout the past two years, I have successfully engineered full-stack solutions integrating Python, JavaScript/TypeScript (React, Node.js), and SQL/NoSQL databases for production projects—including a wildfire IoT detection system, an AI-driven image app, and automation/integration across cloud services (AWS, GCP). While my Java experience is less extensive than my Python and JavaScript work, I have written clean, testable code in Java during university and side projects, and I am highly motivated to develop further in this direction. My approach is always to pick up new languages and frameworks as required to deliver innovative results—evidenced by my rapid adoption of technologies such as Flutter/Dart, Docker, and modern ML frameworks (TensorFlow, PyTorch). 

I thrive in dynamic, multidisciplinary environments and have demonstrated leadership and team collaboration as a Team Leader at Meltdown-Wetherspoons and in academic research teams. My desire to grow is demonstrated by continuous self-improvement, ongoing certification, and seeking projects pushing my boundaries—such as fine-tuning LLMs, building intelligent web automators, and cloud-native ML deployment. I am eager to deepen my full stack and Java expertise within Vable’s engineering-driven and values-led culture, contributing innovative AI features and scaling my impact within your team.
Tell us a little more about your Python:
My Python programming experience spans a range of AI/ML projects, including developing end-to-end pipelines, deploying models, and delivering production-ready solutions such as an IoT-based wildfire detection system and an AI image generation app. Python’s major strengths for AI/ML are its rich ecosystem (TensorFlow, PyTorch, scikit-learn, NLTK, spaCy), concise syntax, and rapid prototyping capabilities, making it my go-to for research, development, and applied data science. Compared to Java, Python streamlines experimentation with cleaner syntax, dynamic typing, and access to cutting-edge libraries, which greatly accelerates iteration in ML workflows.

On the other hand, Java offers advantages in building large-scale, high-performance systems: its static typing, compilation, and mature concurrency support make it preferable for robust, enterprise-grade applications where efficiency and maintainability are priorities. I’d typically opt for Java when integrating AI models into complex backend architectures or where type safety and speed are critical, such as in real-time financial platforms or large SaaS backend services.

In summary, I choose Python for rapid AI development, prototyping, and model training, especially when leveraging the rich Python ML ecosystem. For deploying models into scalable, production environments with strict performance or integration requirements, Java’s strengths become valuable. With both languages, I write clean, modular code and collaborate effectively across engineering teams to deliver reliable AI solutions.
You\u2019re asked to design a model that:
To design a model recommending company Slack channels for new joiners based on their interests, I would begin with a data-driven, user-centric approach:

1. **Data Collection**: Gather relevant data such as new joiners’ profile information (role, department, skills, interests), public Slack channel metadata (topics, activity levels, keywords), and historical join data indicating which types of employees joined which channels.

2. **Interest Extraction (NLP)**: Utilize NLP techniques (spaCy, NLTK, or transformer-based models) to extract and normalize interests from user input, onboarding questionnaires, or HR profiles. Similarly, process the Slack channel descriptions and historical posts to build descriptive embeddings for each channel.

3. **User & Channel Representation**: Represent both users and channels as feature vectors. For users, vectors could capture explicit interests, inferred interests (from role, past experience), and department info. For channels, text embeddings of topics, activity scores, and participant demographics.

4. **Recommendation Algorithm**: Implement a hybrid model:
   - **Content-Based Filtering**: Match user interest vectors to channel embeddings using cosine similarity or nearest neighbor search.
   - **Collaborative Filtering**: Leverage historic data—e.g., new joiners with similar profiles joined certain channels—in a matrix factorization or graph-based recommendation setup.
   - Optionally, use or fine-tune transformer-based models (e.g., BERT) for improved semantic matchmaking between user interests and channel content.

5. **Model Training and Evaluation**: Train on historical join data, optimizing for metrics such as precision, recall, and user engagement post-recommendation. Use validation sets and A/B testing to ensure quality and avoid overfitting.

6. **Explainability & Iteration**: Ensure recommendations come with short explanations (e.g., “You’re recommended #ml-research because you indicated an interest in AI”) for transparency. Gather feedback from users to iteratively refine feature engineering, model input, and output relevance.

7. **Deployment & Monitoring**: Deploy the model as a service integrated with onboarding workflows and Slack’s API, monitor uptake, and use analytics to continuously improve recommendations.

This approach draws on my experience deploying end-to-end ML pipelines, NLP-driven systems, and recommender models (as in my AI image generation app and LLM-based automation projects). With a focus on explainability, robust evaluation, and user-driven iteration, this solution would ensure new joiners integrate quickly and meaningfully into company culture.
You\u2019ve trained an NLP model using s:
When troubleshooting poor named entity recognition (NER) performance with a spaCy model, I would follow a systematic approach to identify and address the root causes. First, I would analyze the dataset quality, ensuring that training data is accurately annotated and sufficiently representative of the entities and contexts relevant to the task. I would check for label inconsistencies or imbalance—since uneven distribution or annotation errors can severely impact model learning—using manual inspection and evaluation metrics.

Next, I would experiment with data augmentation if data is sparse, and consider collecting further annotated samples. I would also evaluate if the default spaCy model or pipeline is appropriate for the domain, and consider leveraging transfer learning by starting from a larger pre-trained model or fine-tuning with domain-specific texts.

Additionally, I’d review hyperparameters such as learning rates and batch sizes, and run experiments adjusting model architecture or adding custom components like entity rulers for specific patterns. To monitor progress, I would utilize evaluation tools—precision, recall, F1, confusion matrices and qualitative error analysis—to identify systematic weaknesses or entity types that aren’t being recognized.

To further improve generalization, I might apply techniques such as cross-validation or introduce regularization to avoid overfitting. I would collaborate with teammates to conduct code and data reviews for additional insights. Documentation and iterative testing would guide the process until the desired performance is achieved. This thorough and collaborative process reflects my hands-on experience with modern NLP pipelines, model evaluation, and data-centric model improvement, as described in your requirements and as practiced in my previous AI engineering and data science projects.
From your experience how does gradient d:
Gradient descent is a method used by AI models to "learn" by gradually improving their performance. Imagine you are at the top of a hill and want to reach the lowest point in a valley. However, it’s very foggy, so you can't see the whole landscape. Instead, you rely on feeling which direction slopes downwards at each step, and you take a small step in that direction. By repeating this process, you steadily get closer to the lowest point. 

Similarly, in training AI models, gradient descent helps the system make small adjustments to its parameters (the "steps") based on how well it’s doing, so that it minimizes errors and gets better over time. This is a step-by-step optimization approach that allows models to become more accurate by learning from their mistakes and correcting them with each iteration.

Why are you interested in a role at Runn:
I am excited about the opportunity to join Runna because I am passionate about leveraging data to drive innovation in health and fitness technology. Your mission to build the #1 training platform for runners and empower users of all levels with personalized coaching aligns closely with my values and professional interests. With a background in Physics, hands-on experience in building scalable ETL pipelines, data-driven applications, and a strong foundation in Python, SQL, and AWS, I am confident I can contribute meaningfully to your cross-functional engineering team.

I am particularly drawn to the collaborative and impact-driven culture at Runna, where engineers play a foundational role in both technology decisions and product direction. The prospect of developing robust data infrastructure, supporting advanced analytics, and delivering actionable insights for a fast-scaling product is both motivating and a great fit for my technical strengths. I am eager to work alongside innovators who value knowledge sharing, continuous improvement, and agile development, and I look forward to helping Runna achieve its vision of becoming the go-to platform for millions of runners worldwide.
What's your favourite problem you've sol:
One of my favourite problems I have solved was the development of a real-time wildfire detection system as part of my research at the University of Sheffield. The challenge involved designing and implementing a robust end-to-end data pipeline that could process and analyze environmental data from distributed IoT sensors using machine learning algorithms. What made this problem stand out was the need to not only achieve high prediction accuracy and early warning capabilities but also create a scalable and efficient system that could operate in real-world, time-sensitive scenarios.

I tackled the project by combining quantitative methods with ETL pipeline development in Python, training Random Forest and Decision Tree models on NASA FIRMS data. I then built a responsive dashboard using Flask and Leaflet.js to visualize alerts and enable interactive monitoring. The solution demonstrated an 86% detection accuracy and provided alerts up to 10 minutes before traditional methods.

This project stands out to me because it required collaboration across software engineering, data science, and product development disciplines—mirroring the cross-functional teamwork Runna values. I enjoyed thoughtfully architecting the system to prioritize data quality, scalability, and actionable insight, all of which align closely with the requirements of this Data Engineer role. The impact of delivering a solution that can meaningfully reduce disaster response times highlighted for me the value of building data-driven platforms with real-world significance—something I am excited to bring to Runna as you continue to scale data-powered coaching and user experience.

One significant example of AI boosting my productivity was during the development of my LinkedIn Job Application Automator project. As someone actively seeking new roles, I noticed that manually applying to hundreds of job postings was time-consuming and inefficient. Leveraging Python and Playwright, I engineered an intelligent automation system that could handle the entire LinkedIn job application process. By integrating OpenAI’s API, the system was able to dynamically generate tailored cover letters and intelligently detect form fields, drastically accelerating the process and ensuring applications were personalised and error-free.

This end-to-end automation allowed me to submit over 400 targeted job applications daily, transforming a process that would have taken several hours into one that took minutes. In addition to significantly streamlining my job search, this project improved my workflow by reducing repetitive manual input, freeing up valuable time for learning and professional development. The experience gave me deeper insights into real-world AI implementation, from prompt engineering to robust workflow automation, and reinforced my passion for integrating AI-driven approaches to solve process inefficiencies—an outlook I’m excited to bring to the AI Automation Coordinator role at Storm Ideas.
